Tau Beta Makes
All Junior Taps,
Two Honoraries
Two honorary and six undergraduate taps have been made
by the Johns Hopkins Chapter
of Tau Beta Pi, national engineering honor society, according
to Tom Owens, president, and
Roger Kane, pledge master.
Dr. Harold E. Hoelscher,
chairman of the Chemical Engineering Department, and Dr.
Robert S. Ayre, chairman of the
Civil Engineering Department,
received honorary taps. The six
undergraduates tapped are Pete
Eller, Tony Bocklage. Joseph
Lassiter, Mason Sisk, George
Vlases, and E. Gerson Stutman.
All are juniors.

DR. MILTON S. EISENHOWER (RIGHT)

Ralph Marterie, who won the Senior Class poll for the
Senior Prom band during June Week, has been signed
according to June Week Chairman Bob Mitgang.
"There should be no slip-up, as the rider which is
usually incorporated in the contract permitting the band
to break the contract for a television appearance is not included in this contract," stated Mitgang.
"We wanted to get the band the class selected, and
we did," Mitgang said. The Prom is set for June 4 al the
Alcazar and will be open to the entire student body. Two

Requirements
According to Kane, membership in the society requires that
the student be in the top fifth
of his class as a senior or the
top eighth as a junior, and that
he show the desired breadth of
interest, unselfish activity, and
promise of future contribution
to the society.
Honorary membership in Tau
Beta "Pi is conferred "for eminent
achievements in engineering" to
those who are ten years or more
past their graduation from college or university. The elections
took place on February 17.

OWEN LATTIMORE

Concerning attendance, Rosenbloom stated, "I'd like to stress
the point that the Junior Prom
is not restricted to juniors.
Everyone at Hopkins is invited.
Phil Rierson will be selling
tickets at $2.00 per couple in the
Levering Hall cafeteria today
and at the door tomorrow
night."
Music will be provided by Bill
Maisel and his " orchestra, an
eleven piece local group with a
featured vocalist. Maisel was
contracted in effort to put the
Prom in the black this year.
Previous junior classes have lost
heavily on their Proms primarily
because of the high cost of bigname orchestras.
Co-chairman Rosenbloom is
confident that the dance will be
conducted "in an orderly, if enthusiastic manner in the more
dignified surroundings of the
Alcazar." Dress will be semiformal; corsages are optional.
As in previous years, setups
will be sold. Tables may be reserved by individuals or groups
by contacting Dave Hochberg,

of the President's Committee on
Governmental C-:ganization, and
acts as a-"good listener." He said
that he does not take part in
partisan politics, and added emphatically that he had no poli
tical aspirations. "I wouldn't have
left Penn State if I did," he said.
Specialized Education
He was asked to explain his
concept of the constitution of a
college education. "Specialization in a particular field is not
enough. The educated person
must be able to make valid judgments in other areas than the
field of his profession. A foundation of understanding in other
fields should be developed. An
education should start the student toward wisdom . . . A student should be commited to a
free way of life."
Freedom To Explore
Earlier, at his inauguration,
Dr. Eisenhower said, "The freedom to explore and interpret
was the
first
monumental
achievement of this University,
and fortunately it has been
sustained here ever since.
"But Johns Hopkins was never
envisaged as a research institute:
It was conceived as a true university, with the teaching function of equal importance and
dignity to that of research."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MARCH 1, 1957

Third Homewood Concert
Scheduled For March 10
By BUDDY MARKS
The third and final concert of
a current series by the Baltimore
Symphony Orchestra will be
given Sunday, March 10, at 4
o'clock in Shriver Hall conducted by Massimo Freccia.
The program includes "Overture, Oberon" by Weber, "Symphony No. 4 in F Minor" by
Tchaikovsky, "El Salon Mexico"

Winners of Sing
To Give Numbers
At Home Concert
In order that the fraternities
have more time to rehearse, the
date of the Inter-fraternity
Sing has been changed to Friday, April 12, announced Glee
Club President Dick Kapp. It
will be held in Shriver Hall at
10 a.m.

Freccia's Background
Dr. Freccia joined the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra in
1952. Prior to that time, he
served as Conductor of the Havana Philharmonic and the New
Orleans Symphony Orchestra.
He studied in Vienna and was
accepted as an apprentice to
Franz Schalk, head of the Vienna State Opera.
Mr. Osmar Steinwald, director
of the Hopkins' music program,
reports an increase in the attendence at the second concert
over that of the first, saying,
"Should we have a similiar increase for this third and final
concert, we may break even
financially."
Primary Interest
Mr. Steinwald stated, "However, I would like to make it
clear that our primary interest
is not a financial one but rather
to bring good music to the
Homewood." He added, "Of
course, whether or not we will
sponsor a series of concerts next
year depends quite heavily on
the patronage of this final concert."

The following night the Glee
Club will present its Home Concert, at which the winning fraternity will receive its award and
will sing its numbers once more.
Kapp also announced that the
Club is looking for an accompanying pianist. Anyone interested should come to Great
Hall in Levering Hall any TuesTickets are priced at $2.00

or at the door on the day of the
concert.

All juniors interested in being
chairman of Orientation Week
in September should contact
Lew Sank, Student Council
President, or the Student Council itself, Box 1246.

and must make a significant
contribution to society in its own

FRIDAY
MARCH 15

SC Plan Making Progress
In Hungarian Fund Drive
The Student Council is making
"good progress' in its plan to
collect $320 as spending money
for the three Hungarian students at Hopkins, according to
Rolf Bessin, chairman of the
Council committee in charge of
raising the money.
• He said, "We have sent out
letters to all campus organizations including clubs and honorary and social fraternities
asking them to donate to this
cause."
Donations Received
"Thus far we have received
$55, $50 from the News-Letter
and $5 from the honorary draMate fraternity, Alpha Psi
Omega. We expect to collect
much more as the letters were
sent out just a few days ago,"
he added.
The money which is collected
Will include, it is hoped, donations from each of the undergraduate classes. It will be used

Editor's Note: This is the
second in a series of articles
submitted by .the Honor Commission describing its activities and
discussing questions or opinions
on all phases of the Honor
System. Questions or comments
Should be submitted to P. O.
Box 24.
As was stated in the first of
these articles, the purpose of this
series is to reemphasize some of
the basic principles of the Honor
System, and to clarify those
situations which may at times
seem hazy to some. Of primary
importance in the successful
functioning of the System is a
thorough understanding of each
individual's personal responsibility under it. There are some who
would like to think that this re-

sponsibility does not include the
reporting of possible violations of
others to the Commission.
They argue that responsibility
with respect to honor lies completely within one's self, and does
not extend to concern with the
moral codes of others. Essentially, this is a valid position, but it
fails to consider one very important point—that the success
and maintenance of the System
depends upon its principles being followed by all. An honor
system which was respected by
only a segment of the undergraduate body would soon cease to
exist.
Ideally, we envision a System
where all are true to its moral
code, where no mechanism for
trying cases of possible viola-

PAGE FIVE

NEWS -LETTER

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MARCH 1, 1957

tions is necessary. Realistically,
however, we are forced to accept
the fact that in a community of
this size, there will be some who
are unwilling to embrace fully
the Honor Code or who are unable at times to repulse the tentacles of temptation, and thus
threaten the continued existence
of the Honor System.
In order to maintain this System and its manifest benefits to
the tremendous majority of the
community, it is necessary that
these few individuals be brought
before the Commission, lest the
continuation of violation by the
few result in a loss to the whole.

CORRESPONDENCE
To the Editors:
I have had occasion to read
a "letter of indignation" concerned expressly with the sport
of beard raising, by Mr. David
Nissman, in your edition of The
News-Letter for February 22, '57.
This response is not a passel
of deploratory remarks pro or
con on the subject of beards and
such paraphernalia in general,
but rather an inquiry of Mr.
Nissman, on what he actually
believes about the growing of
such objects. His letter is a tad
on the paradoxical side: one assumes that the writer disfavors
all such finery; yet to behold
Mr. Nissman himself, one finds
him displaying a generous (if

not en tir ely distinguished)
growth.
A remark was made in the
missive regarding the comparison of disgust associated with
growing a beard to a woman
who does not shave her legs. • ..
There was a time when any respectable man was not without
a beard, and any respectable
woman did not display her legs,
shaved or unshaved.
But Mr. Nissman is a beard
grower, and to take such a diametric stand on the subject,
rather causes one to wonder just
what the old galoot is up to.
Sincerely,
Irene A. Priestley

That's what Alfred E. Morris says
about the Bell System. "Ad that's the
way I like it," he adds. "Right now
I'm in a job I didn't think I'd have for
ten or fifteen years."
The job Al thought was more than
a decade away is Plant Superintendent
for the Hutchinson district in Kansas
with Southwestern Bell. "You can sum
up my work by saying I'm responsible
for the installation and maintenance of
all telephone equipment in a large part
of central Kansas," Al says. "In times
of emergency—a tornado, for instance—
I have complete charge of maintaining
and restoring service."
Here's how Al describes the steps that
led up to his present job: "I started out

in Bell's management training program
in 1951. This gave me an excellent
opportunity to learn about all jobs in
the company—not just the job I'd be
doing. The program was well organized, and I got a la out of it.
"My first assignment was to coordinate a dial conversion in La Crosse,
Kansas, a quarter-million-dollar operation. My next assignments were in
Abilene and Lawrence. Both carried increased responsibility.
"I knew I was moving along pretty
fast—but I was really surprised when
my present job came up. It bears out
what my wife and I thought when I
joined Bell—there'would be great
chances for advancement."

Al Morris graduated in 1951 from the University of Kansas
with a B.S. in Industrial Management. He is typical of many
young men who are finding interesting career opportunities
in Bell Telephone Companies, Bell Telephone Laboratories,
Western Electric and Sandia Corporation. Your placement
officer has more information abont these companies.

Jay Baseballers
To Open Season
Opposing Eagles
Coach Ross Sachs was greeted
by 25 candidates last Tuesday at
the first varsity baseball meeting of the year in the Weight
Room of the Homewood Gym.
Sachs announced that workouts for the Jay batterymen will
begin immediately with the rest
of the squad joining them on
March 11. Coach Sachs urged
each squad member to begin getting in shape prior to the official
opening of workouts, and promised the boys "a lot more running than last year."
The Jay diamondmen will
open their 1957 campaign on
6, against
Saturday, April
American University. Last year,
rain prevented the meeting of
these two squads. The Jays are
scheduled for four consecutive
road games after meeting the
Eagles. The Birds return home
to face the Greyhounds of
Loyola on April 25. The Jays
will also test Swarthmore, Gettysburg, Catholic U. and Western Maryland on the Homewood
diamond.

Jay Improvement Keynoted
In Frosh Cager's Season
"Improvement" was the word
Coach Scott used to characterize
the '56-'57 freshman basketball
team. He went on to explain
that it is very hard for boys who
have all had different basketball
training to mold into a team in
the short time the season lasts.
However, he felt the team
showed good improvement and
better team work toward the
end of the season.
This improvement was climaxed by a 77-60 win over
Western-Maryland last Saturday
in the final game of the season.
Led by Larry Becker's 19 points
and Bob Stava's 14, the Jays
had little trouble in winning
with every man on the team
playing. Joel Gordon, team
manager, also saw action. The
victory enabled the Jays to
avenge an earlier defeat at the
hands of Western-Maryland.
Becker Lauded
With Larry Becker doing most
of the scoring the Jays compiled a record of 8 wins and 5
losses for the season. Becker
averaged 17.9 points and made
73% of his foul shots during

the campaign. Coach Scott was
very pleased with Becker's play
and said he thought he had good
varsity potential.
Bill De Voe and John Gartland were also praised by the
Jay Mentor. DeVoe had a 12.2
average and made 53% of his
foul, shots.
Team Praised
Bob Stava and Scot Hockenberry were cited by Scott as
examples of the most improved
players of the season.
Scott also had praise for Oz
Garcia, Shelly Wollman, Pete
Doyle, Bill McAllister, Hal Stoller, Al Wagner, and Larry
Fesser.

The Garrett Corporation comprises one of the most unique and
giverse research, engineering
and manufacturing organizations
in the world.
The parent company, founded
in 1936, has grown from three persons to nearly 10,000 scientists,
engineeys and production specialists.
From the AiResearch laboratories
have come the pioneer developments
in aircraft components and systems
which have pushed back the barriers of
speed and altitude. Today, 90 per cent of
the free world's aircraft carry this equipment.
Divisions and subsidiaries are also engaged in
creating industrial products in such varied fields as
marine equipment and, turbochargers for diesels, and
in supplying sales and installation engineering services to
airframe companies, airlines'and the military(
Through foreign licensees, Garrett's products and
engineering services now circle the globe.

Garrett's growth has been rapid and its position sound
and stable, mainly because of the creative ability and ideas
of its engineers.

The Applied Physics Laboratory
(APL)of The Johns Hopkins University is a unique organization.
Its professional staff, including
both junior and senior members,
is allowed a measure of responsibility and initiative much greater
than in many other research and
development organizations. A
stimulating environment where
teamwork and individual initiative
are fused results in a high degree
of creativeness and professional
gratification.
For years APL has pioneered:
the first proximity fuze, the first
supersonic ramjet engine, the missiles TERRIER, TALOS and
TARTAR. With a staff of 1275
APL technically directs the Navy's
Bumblebee guided-missile program, including the work of 21
associate and subcontractors,
among them leading universities
and industrial organizations.

Location & Facilities:
The combined facilities of APL
and its contractors provide staff
members with an unparalleled situation for advanced research and
development. APL's own laboratories, recently completed, encompass 350,000 sq. ft. Their locations
in suburban Washington and Baltimore, Md.allow staff members to
enjoy suburban, rural or urban
living and the manifold cultural
and recreational facilities of both
cities.
APL maintains a splendid program of staff benefits, including
financial assistance for advanced
study. Salaries compare favorably
with those of industrial organizations. For detailed information on
staff opportunities for men with
higher-than-average grades contact your Placement. Officer or
write: Professional Staff Appointments.

Editor's Note: This is the
second in a series of articles
submitted by .the Honor Commission describing its activities and
discussing questions or opinions
on all phases of the Honor
System. Questions or comments
Should be submitted to P. O.
Box 24.
As was stated in the first of
these articles, the purpose of this
series is to reemphasize some of
the basic principles of the Honor
System, and to clarify those
situations which may at times
seem hazy to some. Of primary
importance in the successful
functioning of the System is a
thorough understanding of each
individual's personal responsibility under it. There are some who
would like to think that this re-

sponsibility does not include the
reporting of possible violations of
others to the Commission.
They argue that responsibility
with respect to honor lies completely within one's self, and does
not extend to concern with the
moral codes of others. Essentially, this is a valid position, but it
fails to consider one very important point—that the success
and maintenance of the System
depends upon its principles being followed by all. An honor
system which was respected by
only a segment of the undergraduate body would soon cease to
exist.
Ideally, we envision a System
where all are true to its moral
code, where no mechanism for
trying cases of possible viola-

PAGE FIVE

NEWS -LETTER

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MARCH 1, 1957

tions is necessary. Realistically,
however, we are forced to accept
the fact that in a community of
this size, there will be some who
are unwilling to embrace fully
the Honor Code or who are unable at times to repulse the tentacles of temptation, and thus
threaten the continued existence
of the Honor System.
In order to maintain this System and its manifest benefits to
the tremendous majority of the
community, it is necessary that
these few individuals be brought
before the Commission, lest the
continuation of violation by the
few result in a loss to the whole.

CORRESPONDENCE
To the Editors:
I have had occasion to read
a "letter of indignation" concerned expressly with the sport
of beard raising, by Mr. David
Nissman, in your edition of The
News-Letter for February 22, '57.
This response is not a passel
of deploratory remarks pro or
con on the subject of beards and
such paraphernalia in general,
but rather an inquiry of Mr.
Nissman, on what he actually
believes about the growing of
such objects. His letter is a tad
on the paradoxical side: one assumes that the writer disfavors
all such finery; yet to behold
Mr. Nissman himself, one finds
him displaying a generous (if

not en tir ely distinguished)
growth.
A remark was made in the
missive regarding the comparison of disgust associated with
growing a beard to a woman
who does not shave her legs. • ..
There was a time when any respectable man was not without
a beard, and any respectable
woman did not display her legs,
shaved or unshaved.
But Mr. Nissman is a beard
grower, and to take such a diametric stand on the subject,
rather causes one to wonder just
what the old galoot is up to.
Sincerely,
Irene A. Priestley

about the Bell System. "Ad that's the

I have complete charge of maintaining
and restoring service."
Here's how Al describes the steps that
led up to his present job: "I started out

in Bell's management training program
in 1951. This gave me an excellent
opportunity to learn about all jobs in
the company—not just the job I'd be
doing. The program was well organized, and I got a la out of it.
"My first assignment was to coordinate a dial conversion in La Crosse,
Kansas, a quarter-million-dollar operation. My next assignments were in
Abilene and Lawrence. Both carried increased responsibility.
"I knew I was moving along pretty
fast—but I was really surprised when
my present job came up. It bears out
what my wife and I thought when I
joined Bell—there'would be great
chances for advancement."

Al Morris graduated in 1951 from the University of Kansas
with a B.S. in Industrial Management. He is typical of many
young men who are finding interesting career opportunities
in Bell Telephone Companies, Bell Telephone Laboratories,
Western Electric and Sandia Corporation. Your placement
officer has more information abont these companies.

Jay Baseballers
To Open Season
Opposing Eagles
Coach Ross Sachs was greeted
by 25 candidates last Tuesday at
the first varsity baseball meeting of the year in the Weight
Room of the Homewood Gym.
Sachs announced that workouts for the Jay batterymen will
begin immediately with the rest
of the squad joining them on
March 11. Coach Sachs urged
each squad member to begin getting in shape prior to the official
opening of workouts, and promised the boys "a lot more running than last year."
The Jay diamondmen will
open their 1957 campaign on
6, against
Saturday, April
American University. Last year,
rain prevented the meeting of
these two squads. The Jays are
scheduled for four consecutive
road games after meeting the
Eagles. The Birds return home
to face the Greyhounds of
Loyola on April 25. The Jays
will also test Swarthmore, Gettysburg, Catholic U. and Western Maryland on the Homewood
diamond.

Jay Improvement Keynoted
In Frosh Cager's Season
"Improvement" was the word
Coach Scott used to characterize
the '56-'57 freshman basketball
team. He went on to explain
that it is very hard for boys who
have all had different basketball
training to mold into a team in
the short time the season lasts.
However, he felt the team
showed good improvement and
better team work toward the
end of the season.
This improvement was climaxed by a 77-60 win over
Western-Maryland last Saturday
in the final game of the season.
Led by Larry Becker's 19 points
and Bob Stava's 14, the Jays
had little trouble in winning
with every man on the team
playing. Joel Gordon, team
manager, also saw action. The
victory enabled the Jays to
avenge an earlier defeat at the
hands of Western-Maryland.
Becker Lauded
With Larry Becker doing most
of the scoring the Jays compiled a record of 8 wins and 5
losses for the season. Becker
averaged 17.9 points and made
73% of his foul shots during

the campaign. Coach Scott was
very pleased with Becker's play
and said he thought he had good
varsity potential.
Bill De Voe and John Gartland were also praised by the
Jay Mentor. DeVoe had a 12.2
average and made 53% of his
foul, shots.
Team Praised
Bob Stava and Scot Hockenberry were cited by Scott as
examples of the most improved
players of the season.
Scott also had praise for Oz
Garcia, Shelly Wollman, Pete
Doyle, Bill McAllister, Hal Stoller, Al Wagner, and Larry
Fesser.

The Garrett Corporation comprises one of the most unique and
giverse research, engineering
and manufacturing organizations
in the world.
The parent company, founded
in 1936, has grown from three persons to nearly 10,000 scientists,
engineeys and production specialists.
From the AiResearch laboratories
have come the pioneer developments
in aircraft components and systems
which have pushed back the barriers of
speed and altitude. Today, 90 per cent of
the free world's aircraft carry this equipment.
Divisions and subsidiaries are also engaged in
creating industrial products in such varied fields as
marine equipment and, turbochargers for diesels, and
in supplying sales and installation engineering services to
airframe companies, airlines'and the military(
Through foreign licensees, Garrett's products and
engineering services now circle the globe.

Garrett's growth has been rapid and its position sound
and stable, mainly because of the creative ability and ideas
of its engineers.

APL wants graduates eager
to accept the challenge
of responsibility

The Applied Physics Laboratory
(APL)of The Johns Hopkins University is a unique organization.
Its professional staff, including
both junior and senior members,
is allowed a measure of responsibility and initiative much greater
than in many other research and
development organizations. A
stimulating environment where
teamwork and individual initiative
are fused results in a high degree
of creativeness and professional
gratification.
For years APL has pioneered:
the first proximity fuze, the first
supersonic ramjet engine, the missiles TERRIER, TALOS and
TARTAR. With a staff of 1275
APL technically directs the Navy's
Bumblebee guided-missile program, including the work of 21
associate and subcontractors,
among them leading universities
and industrial organizations.

Location & Facilities:
The combined facilities of APL
and its contractors provide staff
members with an unparalleled situation for advanced research and
development. APL's own laboratories, recently completed, encompass 350,000 sq. ft. Their locations
in suburban Washington and Baltimore, Md.allow staff members to
enjoy suburban, rural or urban
living and the manifold cultural
and recreational facilities of both
cities.
APL maintains a splendid program of staff benefits, including
financial assistance for advanced
study. Salaries compare favorably
with those of industrial organizations. For detailed information on
staff opportunities for men with
higher-than-average grades contact your Placement. Officer or
write: Professional Staff Appointments.
